conclusion: Analyze the path of light and conditions for total internal reflection.
A beam of light is incident from the air onto point A on the transparent sphere with an incident angle i.
Assume the refractive index of the sphere is n and that of the air is 1.
According to Snell's law, sin(i) = n sin(r).
For total internal reflection, the angle of incidence inside the medium must exceed the critical angle C.
The critical angle is given by sin(C) = 1/n.
Inside the sphere, the angle of incidence for the second boundary is r.
Total internal reflection will occur if r ≥ C, meaning sin(r) ≥ 1/n.
From the diagram, the light ray i'' inside the sphere is analyzed at point B.
If the angle i'' is greater than or equal to the critical angle C, total internal reflection occurs.
If the incident angle i is large enough, r can exceed the critical angle C.
Light can be totally internally reflected when it is emitted from inside the sphere.
Yes, if the incident angle i is large enough, light can be totally internally reflected when it is emitted from inside the sphere.
